Yes, and I think part of the problem is that people see "trust" as a black & white issue: you either trust somebody or you don't. But especially when taken to a macro level, trust is like money: you can have a little, a lot, none at all, anywhere in between. And as it gradually dissipates, society slowly grows less efficient, less pleasant, less safe and more corrupt. A good illustration is traffic: as drivers generally become ruder, less attentive, less predictable, the roads become more dangerous and clogged. But it's not black & white: there's always another place where drivers have even less trust. As bad as it gets, it can always get worse. Which, on the flip side, means that even when it's gotten pretty bad, there's still an amazing amount of trust. Being social animals, trust is our natural state. If there was literally no trust, no car could move even 1 block without a collision. And every financial transaction would be like a comical kung-fu dance, the buyer holding out the cash while grabbing for the goods, ready to snatch back the jack if the seller grabbed it too soon. Anyone who says "nobody trusts anybody, why should I?" is obviously an idiot.

Knowing how to keep books is one powerful piece of the recipe for 'accountability', as Jake Soll makes clear (as is knowing how to read others' books). The other piece, which also turns up in his piece, is trust. Maurice of Orange didn't open the Dutch East India Company's books to public scrutiny -- but he promised that he had had them closely inspected, and enough people trusted him that the company (and the young Dutch state) survived.

Indeed, trust and faith are everywhere in the language of accounting: just take the phrase "full faith and credit", in which believing appears both in English (faith) and in Latin (credit, lit. 'he believes'). Banks used to be called "trust companies", not by coincidence.

But today's bankers, caught up in their language of "financial innovation" and "maximizing shareholder return" have lost sight of the vital role that trust -- trust anchored in clear accounting -- plays for their business. In the process, they have not only undermined their own industry in deep and lasting ways (do _you_ 'trust' your bank?), but have done immeasurable harm to society as well. For this, as much as for the innumerable shenanigans they have put over on all of us in the last generation, they deserve to be tried and punished.

Too bad our trust in the law has been equally damaged by our legislators and by the legal profession!

"Whoever decided that it was more important for students to know how to apply math than to come out with the right answer when calculating made a grave mistake."

I have to disagree. Knowing how to apply math makes it easier to calculate well. For example, your $9.95 + $9.95 example. Having a facility with mathematical ideas allows you to see that two numbers less than 10, when added, must be less than 20. This is a different skill than going through the memorized mechanics of adding up the columns of two three-digit numbers.

Understanding math enhances ones ability to make calculations and estimates in their head.
